For the past five years, Fotu Katoa has been Utah's director of Pacific Islander Affairs.
His office in downtown Salt Lake City is a virtual Polynesian experience.
Filled with shells and weavings and Polynesian art, the office also includes thick binders on a shelf labeled Utah Meth Task Force, Pacific Island Inmates, Gang File.
Signs of trouble in a population that now numbers close to 30,000 in Utah, says Katoa.
Some in those files, certainly not all, are in them because of a tough transition from the Pacific to the U.S.
mainland.
